EEPORT OF THE NETWORK MANAGER
October 1, 1955
Although the Network member stations have been kept informed through various memo¬
randa and reports, a few remarks on the state of the Network project are appropriate
here.
1. NETWORK MEMBERSHIP. Immediately prior to the 195b NAEB Convention, the Network
had 72 member stations. Since that time seven stations have joined or rejoined
and eight have dropped out, making a present membership of 71 stations.
2. NETWORK PERSONNEL. The Network Headquarters personnel now consists of the
p.qnjvflj ftnt. of "four and one-half full-time employees# Extra workers are picked
up only when necessary. Since this is the first year in which the Network has
been self-supported, we are particularly careful not to make any unnecessary ex¬
penditures or hasty commitments# Nevertheless, it is only fair to say that the
Network Headquarters is working with an absolute minimum in personnel, actually
with one half-time person less than it did two years ago#
3. NETWORK EQUIPMENT. As noted above, the installation of an air conditioner in
our workshop has been helpful in maintaining recording quality, and we hope it
will help in the preservation of our 8,600 tapes. The conversion of the two
mass-duplicators should also be helpful. On the whole, the duplicators have be¬
haved much more respectably during the past year, but they still have not been
completely tamed and they show temperament from time to time. A large part of
the improvement can be credited to Cecil Bidlack, the NAEB Television Engineer,
and Glenn Blackburn, the Networks Assistant Manager for Production, who have
expended much thought and effort on the equipments care.
iu TAPE SUPPLY. The Networks greatest problem at the time of this writing is that
of maintaining an adequate supply of tape at Headquarters to produce recordings
on schedule. The rate of tape-returns decreased considerably this fall with the
result that recordings are being mailed to the stations five days late# Some
stations have 350 unreturned tapes, enough for one-third of a week*s output at
Network Headquarters. Reminders that tape must be returned or traded in order
that the Network may continue operation have been published in the NAEB News¬
letter and the Network cue-sheets, and the Executive Director has telegraphed
requests to several stations for the return of tapes. After all due discussion
and consideration, we have come to the conclusion that for the sake of the ma¬
jority, the Network must discontinue service to those stations which hold up
large quantities of NAEB tape*
NETWORK HEADQUARTERS OPERATION. The Network Headquarters manner of operation
continues much the same as last year. An attempt was made to divide the broad¬
casting year into a summer season and two long seasons, fall-winter and winter¬
spring; but the results of a survey indicated that four thirteen-week seasons,
beginning with the first week of each calendar year, were preferred by the ma¬
jority of the membership, and the Network Headquarters plans to continue on
that basis. A number of changes in clerical methods have been made, and con¬
tinue to be made, in the interests of efficiency and accuracy.
